title: 114_hr5145
content: The text chunk discusses excluding abuse-deterrent formulations of prescription drugs from the Medicaid additional rebate requirement for new formulations of prescription drugs. It also addresses limiting the disclosure of predictive modeling and other analytics technologies to identify and prevent waste, fraud, and abuse. The new section 1128K of the Social Security Act addresses the disclosure of predictive modeling and other analytics technologies to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse. The new section 1128K of the Social Security Act refers to the use of predictive modeling technologies to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse in Medicare, Medicaid, and the Children's Health Insurance Program. Covered algorithms under this section are exempt from disclosure under FOIA. The new section 1128K of the Social Security Act allows the use of covered algorithms for preventing waste, fraud, and abuse in Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program. State agencies can only use these algorithms for administering the State plan or identifying fraud with these programs. State agencies must have data security policies for covered algorithms used in preventing waste, fraud, and abuse in Medicaid and CHIP. Access to information must be restricted to authorized persons, and agencies must follow uniform procedures set by the Secretary. The term "covered algorithm" refers to predictive modeling technology used to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse in Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. Mathematical expressions and development methods are included in this definition. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding Medicaid state plan requirements. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding Medicaid state plan requirements, including providing assurances of compliance with specific subparagraphs to the Secretary. Amendments to the Social Security Act require Medicaid state agencies to ensure compliance with specific subparagraphs of section 1128K(b)(2). The Medicaid Improvement Fund will have $5,000,000 available for expenditures from fiscal year 2021 onwards.
